fields.public_field_1_en: You're walking to work from the bus stop when your phone rings. It's the director of the town's affordable housing developer
John, the affordable Housing Non-profit Director
fields.public_field_2_en: Hi Mayor! The local university just released a report on the future of housing costs in Bayville. Did you know that by 2050, the average family in our town will spend almost half of their income on housing?
fields.public_field_3_en: Thatâ€™s concerning. We need to do something right now.

fields.public_field_1_en: How are you going to prevent that from happening? Choose one of the following strategies.
fields.public_field_2_en: Fund affordable housing production and preservation
fields.public_field_3_en: Raise taxes to generate funds to build a broad range of permanently affordable housing.
fields.public_field_4_en: This would provide a regular stream of funds to address the need for affordable housing.
fields.public_field_5_en: Opponents say that taxes raise the cost of living for everyone and that other funding sources should be used.
fields.public_field_7_en: Require 20 percent of all new housing to be affordable
fields.public_field_8_en: Adopt regulations that require twenty percent of all newly constructed units to be rented at below-market rents.
fields.public_field_9_en: This provides a growing supply of affordable housing that is distributed throughout the region.
fields.public_field_10_en: Opponents say this strategy could limit the total amount of housing that is built by increasing the costs to developers.
fields.public_field_13_en: Implement a suite of renter protection strategies to prevent large rent increases and protect tenants from discrimination by landlords.
fields.public_field_14_en: This strategy would promote more affordable rents and greater stability for renters.
fields.public_field_15_en: Opponents say renter protections could cause some landlords to stop renting out their properties, reducing the overall housing supply.
